did.unittitle: Carl Pope Black Lives Matter movement posters
did.abstract: Carl Pope (1961- ) is an American artist and printmaker. Collection consists of two black-and-white letterpress posters on 22x14 inch cardboard. The first poster reads, "Black lives matter: it ain't what the news told ya!" The second reads, "Is America the America I learned to imagine?" The original posters were created and published in Pope's book, The Appearance of Black Lives Matter (2018). Pope then re-created them in 2020 in response to current Black Lives Matter movement events, distributing copies of the posters to movement participants for the purpose of displaying them in their respective communities. Acquired by the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Carl Robert Pope, Jr., known as Carl Pope, is an African American artist who works primarily in photography, video, and graphic art. Much of his work addresses issues related to race in America, police brutality, and what it means to be Black in America. He has also created artwork that relates to the AIDS epidemic and other social and political issues in the United States. He was born in 1961 in Indianapolis, Indiana and received his arts degrees from Bloomington University in Illinois.

He published the art book The appearance of Black Lives Matter in 2018 with Nicholas Mirzoeff; it is described by the publisher as "An intertextual conversation between artist Carl Pope and writer Nicholas Mirzoeff on the issues surrounding Ferguson, Baltimore and the activism of Black Lives Matter."

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of two text-only letterpress posters on 22x14 inch cardboard sheets, with black lettering on a white background. The first poster reads, "Black lives matter: it ain't what the news told ya!" The second reads, "Is America the America I learned to imagine?"

The original posters were created and published in Carl Pope's book, The Appearance of Black Lives Matter (2018); one appears on the cover. Pope then re-created them in 2020 in response to current Black Lives Matter movement events, distributing copies of these posters to movement participants for the purpose of displaying them in their respective communities.
